biography.bio: Marianne Schönauer was born on May 31, 1920 in Vienna, Austria as Marianne Schifferer. She was an actress, known for Le procès (1948), Der Kurier der Kaiserin (1970) and Eroïca (1949). She died on July 9, 1997 in Vienna.
biography.name: Marianne Schönauer

biography.bio: Wolfgang Lukschy was born on October 19, 1905 in Berlin, Germany. He was an actor and director, known for A Fistful of Dollars (1964), La femme de mes rêves (1944) and Dead Eyes of London (1961). He was married to Viktoria von Schack-Lukschy. He died on July 10, 1983 in West Berlin, West Germany.
biography.name: Wolfgang Lukschy

biography.bio: Dorit Kreysler was born on December 5, 1909 in Mödling, Lower Austria, Austria-Hungary [now Austria] as Dorothea Josephina Friederike Nicoletta Kreisler. She was an actress, known for Geliebter Schatz (1943), Enjoy Yourselves (1934) and Vienna Blood (1942). She was married to Timothé Stuloff. She died on December 16, 1999 in Graz, Austria.
biography.name: Dorit Kreysler

biography.bio: Hans Holt was born on November 22, 1909 in Vienna, Austria-Hungary as Karl Johann Hödl. He was an actor and writer, known for Der Leihopa (1985), Der Bockerer (1981) and La famille Trapp en Amérique (1958). He was married to Renate Bremer. He died on August 3, 2001 in Baden, Lower Austria, Austria.
biography.name: Hans Holt

biography.bio: Whatever her limitations as an actress, Charlott Daudert made up for with wide-eyed effervescence and a cute, feisty personality. The bubbly blonde began working life as editor of the children's section of a newspaper (as 'Aunty Charlotte') in her home town of Königsberg, East Prussia. She also dabbled in drafting costume designs. The abandonment of her journalistic career seems to have come about all of a sudden and quite by accident: accompanying a friend to a theatrical audition as 'moral support' resulted in Charlotte, not the friend, being signed up for drama school. Her 'discovery' is generally credited to the renowned actor Max Pallenberg who took on the role of her mentor. Known by her peers as 'Charly', she made her debut in a minuscule part in Shakespeare's "Much Ado About Nothing" and spent the next three years at Tilsit's Stadttheater under Pallenberg's direction. Following a brief stint in local radio, she then moved on to wider canvases in Berlin where she underwent further tuition by Leopold Jessner. By 1933, Charly had developed into an accomplished comedienne and come to the attention of Trude Hesterberg. She began performing comedy routines and singing in various popular cabarets, including "Musenschaukel" and "Die Katakombe". At the same time, she spiced up the screen as perpetually naive, sexy friends of the heroine. Her output was rather heavily weighted towards escapist entertainments, some of them not at all bad: April, April! (1935), Der Etappenhase (1937), Kitty et la conférence mondiale (1939). Resuming in the same vein in the aftermath of World War II, the ever likeable, pert, dizzy Charlott warbled a popular hit song ("Ach du liebe Zeit, hat den kein Mensch mehr für die Liebe Zeit") in the ruins of Berlin in Nacht ohne Sünde (1950). There were diverse other supporting roles in box-office hits, including the caper comedies Klettermaxe (1952) and Der blaue Stern des Südens (1951). Sadly, despite her enduring popularity as a conveyor of uncomplicated happiness, genuine stardom was never to be on the cards. The decline of Charly's career was to be exacerbated by depression and alcoholism. On occasion, she would come on stage and forget or fumble her lines. By the autumn of 1960, she was making plans to retire from acting and run an artists B & B in Monaco. It never came to pass. Just four months later she was dead from a blood disorder at the age of 47.
biography.name: Charlott Daudert

biography.bio: Kurt Seifert was born on July 4, 1903 in Essen, Germany. He was an actor and writer, known for Eine Nacht im Separee (1950), Robert and Bertram (1939) and Wenn Männer schwindeln (1950). He died on December 3, 1950 in Berlin, Germany.
biography.name: Kurt Seifert

biography.bio: Carsta Löck was born on December 28, 1902 in Deezbüll, Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. She was an actress, known for Emil and the Piglet (1973), Emil i Lönneberga (1971) and Vier Stunden von Elbe 1 (1968). She died on October 19, 1993 in Berlin, Germany.
biography.name: Carsta Löck

biography.bio: Erika von Thellmann was born on August 31, 1902 in Leutschau, Austria-Hungary. She was an actress, known for The Good Soldier Schweik (1960), Willi Manages the Whole Thing (1972) and Leben wie die Fürsten (1966). She was married to Tino Pattiera. She died on October 27, 1988 in Calw, Baden-Württemberg, West Germany.
biography.name: Erika von Thellmann

biography.bio: Hans Zesch-Ballot was born on May 20, 1896 in Dresden, Germany. He is known for his work on Eine schwere Entscheidung (1958), Kleines Intermezzo (1938) and Wie einst im Mai (1938). He died on September 1, 1972 in Munich, Bavaria, West Germany.
biography.name: Hans Zesch-Ballot

biography.bio: Carl Napp is an actor, known for Das Sonntagskind (1956), Träumerei (1944) and Ne craignez pas les grosses bêtes (1953).
biography.name: Carl Napp

biography.bio: Kurt Großkurth was born on May 11, 1909 in Langenselbold, Hesse, Germany. He was an actor, known for Ludwig - Le crépuscule des Dieux (1973), August (1961) and Landarzt Dr. Brock (1967). He was married to Martel Großkurth. He died on May 29, 1975 in Bad Aibling, Bavaria, Germany.
biography.name: Kurt Großkurth
